options.text: Generally moderate to good visibility, haze, sometimes few or scattered cumulus.
Overcast by medium and high clouds, stratus with drizzle, poor visibility.
Moderate to poor visibility, fog or stratus, stratocumulus and drizzle.
Generally good visibility outside the frequent showers of CBs.

options.text: the angle of incidence of the solar radiation is very small in polar regions.
the velocity induced by earth`s rotation of a point on the earth`s surface is smaller near the poles.

variant.question: (Refer to Annex) Considering Melbourne in July, the weather is predominantly influenced by the zone of...

options.text: subtropical high pressure, with the occasional passage of fronts originating in the adjacent zone of westerly waves
Antarctic high pressure due to the absence of any protective land mass between south Australia and Antarctica
low pressure areas of temperate latitudes, bringing an almost continuous succession of fronts resulting in strong winds, low cloud and rain
equatorial low pressure due to the proximity of the intertropical convergence zone over central Australia

What is the type, intensity and seasonal variation of precipitation in the equatorial region?

options.text: Rainshowers, hail showers and thunderstorms occur the whole year, but frequency is highest during two periods: April - May and October - November.
Precipitation is generally in the form of showers but continuous rain occurs also. The greatest intensity is in July.
Warm fronts are common with continuous rain. The frequency is the same throughout the year.
Showers of rain or hail occur throughout the year; the frequency is highest in January.

variant.question: Why is it warmer at the tropics and equatorial regions than at the poles?

options.text: The inclination angle of the Earth causes a very small angle of incidence of the solar radiation in polar regions.
Due to the characteristics of the surface of the Earth.
The rotation of the Earth causes a slower speed close to the poles.
Due to the cold sea in polar regions.
